Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Community-Based 3D Imaging That Ties Clinoform Geometry to Facies Successions and Neogene Sea-Level Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary goal of this project is to constrain the complex forcing functions tying evolution and preservation of the margin stratigraphic record to base-level changes. These processes include eustasy, climatic and paleooceanographic variations, tectonism, compaction and rates of sediment supply. Existing borehole data will provide lithostratigraphy, geochronology and paleobathymetry. Geomorphology revealed by horizontal slices (among other 3D imaging tools) will identify diagnostic features such as river systems, shorelines, delta channels, sediment failure scars, etc., none of which can be resolved in existing 2D seismic data to the degree required to map shifting shallow-water depositional settings in the vicinity of clinoform rollovers. For the general benefit of a broad user community the PIs will coordinate and acquire a 3D seismic data encompassing the three IODP drillsites on the inner-middle shelf of the New Jersey (NJ) continental margin on R/V Marcus Langseth. Data will be made available to the engaged scientific community to use as the foundation of follow-on, PI- driven proposals that improve understanding of factors shaping the NJ margin in particular, and that imprint the sedimentary record at continental margins in general. 3D seismic imaging can now be applied to the NJ margin to put these sampled records in a spatially accurate, stratigraphically meaningful context. Such imagery will allow researchers to map sequences around drill sites with a resolution and confidence previously unattainable, and to analyze their spatial/temporal evolution. Objectives include: 1) establishing the impact of known Ice House base-level changes on the stratigraphic record; 2) providing greater understanding of the response of near-shore environments to changes in elevation of global sea level (with special relevance to the current relentless rise), and 3) determining the amplitudes/timing of global sea-level changes during the mid-Cenozoic, which should help humanity put anthropogenic base-level change in a proper long-term context.

Broader Impacts

The project will collaboratively engage the scientific community and generate widely accessible data for all users. Students and early-career scientists will be mentored and involved in the cruise. The PIs will produce exhibits and/or lectures hosted by the Rutgers Geology Museum. Since the source of the sedimentary record offshore New Jersey fed a similar pulse of sediments into the Gulf of Mexico, increasing knowledge of the evolution of the NJ shelf may help improve strategies for hydrocarbon exploration in the Gulf.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Texas at Austin Institute for Geophysics

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative project between Rutgers University and the University of Texas Institute for Geophysics (including a co-Principal Investigator from Dalhousie University, Canada, appointed as an Institute for Geophysics Research Fellow) imaged New Jersey continental shelf sedimentary successions by acquiring a 3D seismic volume in 2015. These strata, deposited during the last 40 million years, are known from previous research to be indicative of relative sea-level change and had been successfully sampled during Integrated Ocean Discovery Program (IODP) Expedition 313 in 2009.  The survey plan called for collection of 3D seismic data by R/V Marcus Langseth across 600 km2 of the New Jersey continental shelf in a 50 km by 12 km rectangle encompassing the three Expedition 313 drill-sites. The survey used an innovative hybrid seismic acquisition system combining a single 3 km-long hydrophone streamer and a “P-Cable” spread comprising 24 x 50 m-long parallel hydrophone streamers. This combination is designed to optimize the seismic velocity control provided by the long streamer, and necessary for the data processing required to create seismic images, with the high-resolution imaging necessary for the targeted shallow stratigraphic section.  Per the grant specification, commercial data processing has since been carried out by Absolute Imaging and DECO Geophysical, along with subcontractors.

 

The scientific goal is to provide improved understanding of the factors shaping this part of the sedimentary record off New Jersey, which typifies many similar successions worldwide, including the long-term history of global sea-level change and, in particular, the record of shoreline migration on this part of the heavily populated east coast of the United States. Because ~10% of humanity lives along continental margins, knowledge of the interaction of the sedimentary record with ongoing sea-level changes serves relevant societal interests. This is a “community” project: the 3D volume, when fully processed, will be made freely available to all scientists to use as the foundation of follow-on research proposals that improve understanding of factors shaping the New Jersey margin and that also influence the sedimentary record at continental margins globally.

 

Difficulties affecting data processing arose from uncertainties in fixing the positions of all source and receiver components in the complex acquisition system. Resolving these navigational issues has delayed release of the data. However, release of the processed data to the scientific community is now imminent (as of March 2018). We believe that these data will meet scientific expectations: preliminary processed images reveal well-defined channels, probably formed by fluvial processes when the continental shelf was exposed by shoreline migration during relative sea-level falls. Furthermore, the concept of using a hybrid system to image successions of this type in shelfal water depths has been proven. The associated navigational challenges are significant, but are now well understood; future hybrid surveys will benefit from our study. In addition, as a result of experience gained during the 2015 cruise, modifications may be made to the P-Cable, now owned by Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, to make it more robust.

 

The project has incorporated from the outset a strong educational component; 11 graduate students participated in the two cruises required to complete the survey. These students gained valuable experience in marine seismic operations; one of these students has subsequently worked on the data as part of his Ph.D. research.
